comment.author: 30269856@N02
comment._content: I imagine the people at the National Archives will be able to help with regard to who took the picture ...

comment.author: 31575009@N05
comment._content:
Actually our Ministry of Information file on this is very, very scanty. It's a large print and a negative on Kodak safety film and that's pretty much it.

We'd love to have more information: that's why we're here!

(I should perhaps add that I believe NARA hold the same image)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A similar photo from the Library of Congress collections is at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3a10098

comment.author: 47067175@N05
comment._content: The original of this photograph is held by the Imperial War Museum which is the place of deposit for all British photographs relating to the Second World War.  If anyone has any queries about who took this please contact photos@iwm.org.uk

comment._content: great photograph

comment.author: 16044367@N00
comment._content: Similar vantage point to this one taken on Kodachrome. www.amazon.ca/Kodachrome-American-Invention-World-1939-19...

comment.author: 49187576@N00
comment._content: A bit lilac. The national archives should delete the irreverent comments!

comment.author: 95338125@N00
comment._content:
I think it's ENCOURAGING to see The National Archives opening up access to these photographs by uploading them to flickr and then in keeping with the culture of the community, allowing users humor and social interaction. It's important to note that this photostream IS NOT The National Archives, not a mausoleum, it's still flickr! You can reserve all your (appropriate) stodginess for when you visit the real article at Kew. 

The more people comment, the more other people will view the photographs.

comment.author: 49187576@N00
comment._content: I was being ironic (note my exclamation mark). I still think it's lilac.

comment.author: 95338125@N00
comment._content: Ha, oh.

comment.author: 13866913@N06
comment._content: Thank you for adding this interesting photo. Churchill looks uncomfortable, as if uninvited (is he Europe?), holding on to his hat (has he just arrived?) and crossing his feet. While Roosevelt, his left foot pointing towards Stalin, has turned his head the other way, towards Churchill, as if saying to him ¨You´re still here, are you?¨. Stalin also seems tense, wringing his hands and hiding his thumbs. There again, I may be reading too much into it and it´s just a remarkable picture. Praise to the photographer for freezing this moment in time!

comment.author: 64320663@N03
comment._content: Really nice photograph! I remember that this picture was in my history book in High School, brings back memories!

comment.author: 53976326@N07
comment._content: Fantastic! I've always seen this shot in b/w while reading about these people and now, all of a sudden, they seem alive! The power of photography, eh? Roosevelt, I believe was already gravely ill and Churchill was only a little better. Stalin, alas, was going strong although already an underdog in cold war spirit.
